misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Hidden belief that the prompt controls/validates input
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that printing the prompt "Enter 5 integers:" is what makes the program receive exactly 5 integers, and that the user will naturally comply (so no extra validation is needed).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `System.out.print(...)` only outputs text; it has no connection to `Scanner` and cannot enforce how many values the user enters or whether they are integers. The loop (`for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)`) is the actual mechanism that attempts to read 5 integers, and `nextInt()` will throw an exception if the next token isn’t an integer. If the user enters fewer than 5 ints, the program will block waiting for more input.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Can lead to blocking (waiting for more input) or a runtime exception (`InputMismatchException`) if non-integers are entered; not a compile error.
